standard_metadata.standard_description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Add and subtract mixed numbers with unlike denominators (no regrouping)

hints.content: Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} + \blueD4 \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonE{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueE{0} &\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ +&\blueE{4}&\maroonE{\dfrac{2}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonE4$ and $\maroonE5$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD4$ and $\maroonD5$ is $\maroonD{20}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \times {\dfrac{5}{5}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{20}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} \times {\dfrac{4}{4}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{20}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonE{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueE{0} &\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{20}}\\\\ +&\blueE{4}&\maroonE{\dfrac{8}{20}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonE{\dfrac{13}{20}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueE{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\,\,\blueE{0} &\maroonE{\dfrac{5}{20}}\\\\ +&\,\,\blueE{4}&\maroonE{\dfrac{8}{20}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\,\,\blueE{4}&\maroonE{\dfrac{13}{20}} \end{align}$
$\maroonE{\dfrac{1}{4}} + \blueE4 \maroonE{\dfrac{2}{5}} =  \blueE{} \maroonE{\dfrac{13}{20}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} + \blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{0} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}\\\\ +&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD6$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD6$ is $\maroonD{6}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \times {\dfrac{1}{1}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{0} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}}\\\\ +&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{0} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}}\\\\ +&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} \end{align}$
$ \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} + \blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} =  \blueD{2} \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD8 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\\\\ +&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD6$ and $\maroonD{4}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD6$ and $\maroonD{4}$ is $\maroonD{12}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{12}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{12}}\\\\ +&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{12}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{12}}\\\\ +&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD{8}&\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{12}} \end{align}$
$\blueD8 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} + \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}} = \blueD{8}\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{12}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD1 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{8}} + \blueD3 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{8}}\\\\ +&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD8$ and $\maroonD3$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD8$ and $\maroonD3$ is $\maroonD{24}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{8}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{8}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{9}{24}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} \times {\dfrac{8}{8 }} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{24}}\\\\ +&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{17}{24}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{24}}\\\\ +&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD4&\maroonD{\dfrac{17}{24}} \end{align}$
$\blueD1 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{8}} + \blueD3 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} = \blueD4\maroonD{\dfrac{17}{24}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{7}} + \blueD4 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{7}}\\\\ +&\blueD{4}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD7$ and $\maroonD2$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD7$ and $\maroonD2$ is $\maroonD{14}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{7}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{7}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{14}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \times {\dfrac{7}{7}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{14}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{14}}\\\\ +&\blueD{4}&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{14}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{14}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{14}}\\\\ +&\blueD{4}&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{14}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD6&\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{14}} \end{align}$
$\blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{7}} + \blueD4 \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} = \blueD6\maroonD{\dfrac{11}{14}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD3 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} + \blueD6\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\\\ +&\blueD{6}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{10}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{10}$ is $\maroonD{10}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \times {\dfrac{1}{1}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ +&\blueD{6}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ +&\blueD{6}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD9&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}} \end{align}$
$\blueD3 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} + \blueD6\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} = \blueD9\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} + \blueD7\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\\\ +&\blueD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD{4}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD{4}$ is $\maroonD{12}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} \times {\dfrac{4}{4}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{12}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{12}}\\\\ +&\blueD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{12}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{12}}\\\\ +&\blueD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD{12}&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{12}} \end{align}$
$\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} + \blueD7\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} = \blueD{12}\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{12}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by adding each piece.   $\blueD4\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} + \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}$

First, let's add the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\\\ +&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can add.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD2$ and $\maroonD{5}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD2$ and $\maroonD{5}$ is $\maroonD{10}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \times {\dfrac{5}{5}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}} \end{align}$
Now, we can add our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\\\ +&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}} \end{align}$

Next, let's add the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\\\ +&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD{5}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}} \end{align}$
$\blueD4\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} + \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} = \blueD{5}\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}} -  \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD4$ and $\maroonD{16}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD4$ and $\maroonD{16}$ is $\maroonD{16}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \times {\dfrac{4}{4}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{12}{16}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}} \times {\dfrac{1}{1}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{12}{16}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{16}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\maroonD{\dfrac{12}{16}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{16}} \end{align}$
$\blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{16}} = \blueD2 \maroonD{\dfrac{7}{16}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD{4}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD3$ and $\maroonD{4}$ is $\maroonD{12}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} \times {\dfrac{4}{4}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{12}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{12}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{12}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{12}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD5&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{12}} \end{align}$
$\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} = \blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{12}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD8\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{2}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{2}$ is $\maroonD{10}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{10}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \times {\dfrac{5}{5}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{10}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{10}}\\\\ -&\blueD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD8&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
$\blueD8\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{5}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}} = \blueD8\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD7\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} - \blueD2\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\\\ -&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{10}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{10}$ is $\maroonD{10}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \times {\dfrac{1}{1}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ -&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{10}}\\\\ -&\blueD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD5&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
$\blueD7\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}} - \blueD2\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}} = \blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{10}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD4\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} - \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD6$ and $\maroonD{3}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD6$ and $\maroonD{3}$ is $\maroonD{6}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} \times {\dfrac{1}{1}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{4} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD3&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \end{align}$
$\blueD4\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}} - \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{3}} = \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}} - \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD8$ and $\maroonD{3}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD8$ and $\maroonD{3}$ is $\maroonD{24}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{15}{24}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} \times {\dfrac{8}{8}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{15}{24}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{24}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\maroonD{\dfrac{15}{24}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{24}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{24}} \end{align}$
$\blueD5\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}} - \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}} = \blueD2\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{24}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{9}} - \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{9}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD9$ and $\maroonD{6}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD9$ and $\maroonD{6}$ is $\maroonD{18}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{4}{9}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{9}} \times {\dfrac{2}{2}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{18}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} \times {\dfrac{3}{3}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{18}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{18}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{18}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{18}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{3} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{18}}\\\\ -&\blueD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{18}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{18}} \end{align}$
$\blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{9}} - \blueD1\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}} = \blueD2\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{18}}$
Each mixed number has a $\blueD{\text{whole number}}$ and a $\maroonD{\text{fraction}}$. Let's start by subtracting each piece.   $\blueD6\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} - \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$

First, let's subtract the $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{6} &\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ \end{align}$  Our denominators need to be the same so we can subtract.   What is the least common multiple for the denominators $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{4}$?

The least common multiple of $\maroonD5$ and $\maroonD{4}$ is $\maroonD{20}$.  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} \times {\dfrac{4}{4}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{20}}\\\\ \maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}&=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \times {\dfrac{5}{5}} = \maroonD{\dfrac{5}{20}} \end{align}$
Now, we can subtract our $\maroonD{\text{fractions}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{6} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{20}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{20}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{20}} \end{align}$

Next, let's subtract the $\blueD{\text{whole numbers}}$.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{6} &\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{20}}\\\\ -&\blueD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{20}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\blueD3&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{20}} \end{align}$
$\blueD6\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{5}} - \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}} = \blueD3\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{20}}$
